dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, big news coming out of California, especially for anyone who uses, or like, drives for Uber and Lyft. It's, uh, all about AB5.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, big news coming out of California, especially for anyone who uses, or like, drives for Uber and Lyft. It's, uh, all about A B five.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: California lawmakers passed Assembly Bill 5 on Wednesday, which largely requires companies to convert independent contractors to employees if their work is part of the companys main business or the company exerts control over their work.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it really is. And Uber, for its part, is really digging in its heels. They've just announced they're prepared to fight *all* legal challenges.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it really is. And Uber, for its part, is really digging in its heels. They've just announced they're prepared to fight all legal challenges.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Instead, Uber says it is prepared to fight any legal challenges in court and has set aside an additional $30 million for a ballot measure to provide workers with other benefits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and they've even, uh, put aside an additional $30 million for a ballot measure. Like, wow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and they've even, uh, put aside an additional thirty million dollars for a ballot measure. Like, wow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Instead, Uber says it is prepared to fight any legal challenges in court and has set aside an additional $30 million for a ballot measure to provide workers with other benefits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm. And their chief legal officer, Tony West, he's basically saying they're going to continue to fight these misclassification claims in court, you know, just like they always have.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm. And their chief legal officer, Tony West, he's basically saying they're going to continue to fight these misclassification claims in court, you know, just like they always have.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We expect we will continue to respond to claims of misclassification in arbitration and in court as necessary, just as we do now, Tony West, Ubers chief legal officer, told reporters during a press call on Wednesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, what's their big argument here? Because AB5 seems pretty clear about converting contractors to employees if it's their main business.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what's their big argument here? Because A B five seems pretty clear about converting contractors to employees if it's their main business.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: California lawmakers passed Assembly Bill 5 on Wednesday, which largely requires companies to convert independent contractors to employees if their work is part of the companys main business or the company exerts control over their work.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, see, Uber's argument is that their main business isn't drivers and rides, it's actually, like, being a technology platform.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, see, Uber's argument is that their main business isn't drivers and rides, it's actually, like, being a technology platform.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Uber argues its main business is not drivers and rides, but being a technology platform for several different types of digital marketplaces.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] A technology platform? Uh, for rides?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A technology platform? Uh, for rides?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! They also point out that drivers can be signed into multiple services at once, you know, Lyft, food delivery, all that. So they're not *just* Uber.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! They also point out that drivers can be signed into multiple services at once, you know, Lyft, food delivery, all that. So they're not just Uber.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It also allows drivers to be signed into multiple services, from Lyft to food delivery companies, at once.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but AB5 is set to take effect in January, and they're not automatically reclassifying anyone? That's... defiant.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but A B five is set to take effect in January, and they're not automatically reclassifying anyone? That's... defiant.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Because the company believes its workers will still be classified correctly under the new measure, West said Uber will not be automatically reclassifying drivers to be employees in January, when the measure is likely to take effect.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally defiant. West said they won't be automatically reclassifying drivers. And actually, both Uber and Lyft stock closed in the green on Thursday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally defiant. West said they won't be automatically reclassifying drivers. And actually, both Uber and Lyft stock closed in the green on Thursday.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Both Uber and Lyft stock closed in the green on Wednesday on the news that Governor Gavin Newsom, who had already promised to sign the ball, remains in talks with the companies, as first reported by the Wall Street Journal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Really? Why's that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Really? Why's that?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, apparently Governor Newsom, who'd already promised to sign the bill, is still in talks with the companies. So, there's, like, a glimmer of hope for them, I guess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, apparently Governor Newsom, who'd already promised to sign the bill, is still in talks with the companies. So, there's, like, a glimmer of hope for them, I guess.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Both Uber and Lyft stock closed in the green on Wednesday on the news that Governor Gavin Newsom, who had already promised to sign the ball, remains in talks with the companies, as first reported by the Wall Street Journal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Interesting. It really feels like a repeat of their early days, doesn't it? Just, like, challenging the existing rules.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Interesting. It really feels like a repeat of their early days, doesn't it? Just, like, challenging the existing rules.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Ubers defiant stance is a throwback to its earliest days of ride-hailing where it made similar arguments that existing laws around taxis and transportation also didnt apply to its business.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It really does. I mean, the gig economy was built on this model of flexible workers, right? But now, uh, AB5 is threatening that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really does. I mean, the gig economy was built on this model of flexible workers, right? But now, uh, A B five is threatening that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The gig economy was largely built off companies from Uber to TaskRabbit to DoorDash utilizing independent employees who could set their own schedules, but didnt receive benefits like healthcare.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And so, Uber and Lyft, they're working together on this new ballot measure, which would offer, like, *fewer* benefits than AB5, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And so, Uber and Lyft, they're working together on this new ballot measure, which would offer, like, fewer benefits than A B five, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As part of its response, Uber is also coordinating with its rival Lyft to propose a new ballot measure that would offer better benefits for their independent contractor workforce, including a base pay rate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's the plan. They tried to float it as a compromise before AB5 passed, but it didn't work. Now they're taking it straight to the voters, hoping, uh, they'll see it their way.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the plan. They tried to float it as a compromise before A B five passed, but it didn't work. Now they're taking it straight to the voters, hoping, uh, they'll see it their way.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The companies had tried to float it as a compromise during the bill talks, but AB5 passed regardless.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, they're really just trying to bypass the legislature entirely.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, they're really just trying to bypass the legislature entirely.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Lyft even put thirty million in too, and said the state "missed an opportunity" with AB5, complaining about all the carve-outs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Lyft even put thirty million in too, and said the state "missed an opportunity" with A B five, complaining about all the carve-outs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lyft, who also committed $30 million to the ballot measure, said the state had missed an important opportunity when it came to regulating the space. The fact that there were more than 50 industries carved out of AB5 is very telling, Lyft said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, it's going to be a big fight, then, with a lot of money involved.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it's going to be a big fight, then, with a lot of money involved.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. They're prepared to, uh, take this issue to the voters to "preserve the freedom and access" drivers want. It's gonna be wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. They're prepared to, uh, take this issue to the voters to "preserve the freedom and access" drivers want. It's gonna be wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We are fully prepared to take this issue to the voters of California to preserve the freedom and access drivers and riders want and need.
